skill.name: generating-solana-projects
skill.description: Generates complete Solana blockchain projects with Anchor framework (v0.32.1) and Next.js frontend including Rust smart contracts, tests, and wallet integration. Use when creating Solana dApps, NFT marketplaces, token programs, DAOs, DeFi protocols, or when user mentions Solana, Anchor, or blockchain projects.
skill.summary: Generates complete Solana blockchain projects with Anchor framework (v0.32.1) and Next.js frontend i...
skill.author: MSzgy

security_audit.summary: Static analysis detected documentation patterns misidentified as code execution. All findings are markdown examples of legitimate Solana development commands (anchor, solana-test-validator). No actual shell execution, credential exfiltration, or malicious behavior exists. Risk factors represent standard dev tooling documentation.

low_findings.title: Documentation Patterns Misidentified as Code Execution
low_findings.description: Static scanner detected backtick syntax in markdown files as shell command execution. These are markdown code block formatting and documentation examples showing bash commands like `anchor keys list`, `anchor build`, `anchor deploy`. No actual code execution occurs.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Backticks are markdown syntax for code blocks, not Ruby/shell execution. All detected patterns are documentation of Solana development commands.

low_findings.title: Hardcoded URLs Are Standard Configuration
low_findings.description: Detected hardcoded URL https://api.apr.dev (Solana registry) and localhost IP 127.0.0.1. These are legitimate configuration values for Solana development, not credential exfiltration or malicious network calls.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: URLs are standard Solana registry API endpoint and localhost development endpoint. No sensitive data transmission occurs.

low_findings.title: Path Traversal in Templates Is Legitimate
low_findings.description: Path sequences like ../../../target/idl/ are legitimate relative import paths in generated project templates. These are proper relative paths for project structure, not path traversal vulnerabilities.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Templates use standard relative imports for generated project structure. No untrusted input or file system access vulnerabilities.

content.value_statement: Creating Solana blockchain projects from scratch requires understanding Anchor framework conventions, Rust smart contract structure, and Next.js frontend integration. This skill generates complete production-ready projects with proper structure, configuration, and wallet integration.
actual_capabilities: Generates complete Anchor framework project structure (v0.32.1) with proper directories and configuration
Creates Rust smart contract files: lib.rs, state.rs, errors.rs, and instruction handlers
Produces TypeScript test files with Anchor testing framework setup
Builds Next.js frontend with Solana wallet adapter integration
Generates all configuration files: Anchor.toml, Cargo.toml, package.json, tsconfig.json
limitations: Does not execute shell commands or deploy contracts - generates code for user to deploy
Does not interact with live Solana networks or blockchain state
Does not generate audit reports or security assessments for smart contracts
Does not provide legal or regulatory guidance for token launches

use_cases.title: Quick Start New Solana dApp
use_cases.description: Create a production-ready Solana project with Anchor and Next.js in seconds instead of manually setting up project structure, configuration files, and boilerplate code.
use_cases.target_user: Developers new to Solana who want to start building quickly

use_cases.title: Standardize Project Structure
use_cases.description: Generate consistent project templates across a team with proper Anchor conventions, ensuring all projects follow the same structure and best practices.
use_cases.target_user: Engineering teams building multiple Solana applications

use_cases.title: Learn Solana Development
use_cases.description: Understand proper Solana project organization by examining generated code with clear separation between smart contracts, tests, and frontend components.
use_cases.target_user: Developers learning Solana and Anchor framework

prompt_templates.title: Basic Project Creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Solana project with Anchor framework for a [project-type: voting system/NFT marketplace/token staking] called [project-name]
prompt_templates.scenario: Generate a complete Solana blockchain project

prompt_templates.title: Custom Features
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Solana Anchor project named [name] with the following features: [list instructions] and state: [list state accounts]
prompt_templates.scenario: Generate project with custom smart contract features

prompt_templates.title: Full Stack with Frontend
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a complete Solana dApp with Anchor backend and Next.js frontend including [list frontend components]
prompt_templates.scenario: Create full-stack project with frontend integration

prompt_templates.title: Reference Templates
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me the reference template for [Anchor.toml configuration / Rust lib.rs / TypeScript tests / Next.js wallet setup]
prompt_templates.scenario: Get specific code templates for manual customization

output_examples.input: Create a Solana voting DAO project
output: â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ src/lib.rs (with initialize, vote, close instructions)
- Frontend: staking dashboard with APY display

best_practices: Always run `anchor keys list` to generate new program ID before deployment
Update program ID in three locations: Anchor.toml, lib.rs declare_id!, and frontend anchorSetup.ts
Build with `anchor build` before deploying to generate IDL and TypeScript types
Test on localnet with `solana-test-validator` before deploying to devnet
anti_patterns: Do not deploy without updating program IDs in all required locations
Do not skip the `anchor build` step - frontend depends on generated IDL
Do not use different Anchor versions - stick to 0.32.1 for compatibility
Do not hardcode private keys - use wallet files and proper security practices

faq.question: What versions does this skill use?
Does this skill deploy contracts to Solana?
faq.answer: No. The skill generates project files only. Users must run anchor build, anchor deploy, and anchor test commands themselves.

faq.question: What frontend framework is included?
faq.answer: Next.js 14 with TypeScript, Solana wallet adapter for React, and basic UI components for wallet connection.

faq.question: Can I customize the generated project?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill generates templates that can be modified. Use reference.md for specific code templates to customize.

faq.question: What test framework is used?
faq.answer: Anchor testing framework with Mocha, Chai, and ts-mocha for TypeScript smart contract tests.

faq.question: Do I need Solana CLI installed?
faq.answer: Yes. Users need Rust, Solana CLI 1.18+, and Anchor CLI 0.32.1 installed to use generated projects.
